title: Newtons second law - four blocks two ways

content.question: Three large blocks, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, and a small block attached to Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> slide across a horizontal surface as a constant force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> is exerted on Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, as shown in the figure. There is negligible friction between the blocks and the horizontal surface. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> pushes Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> with a force <math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math>. The small block is then removed from Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and attached to Block <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> and the same force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> is exerted on Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>. How does <math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> compare in the second situation to the first situation and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> is not the same as the first situation because Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> now has the same acceleration but a different mass.

<math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> is not the same as the first situation because Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> now has a different acceleration.

<math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> is the same as the first situation because Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is also being pushed by Block <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> by the same amount in both situations.

<math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> is the same as the first situation because the net force on Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is the same in both situations.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> is the same as the first situation because the net force on Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is the same in both situations.
